projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Epithalamium VPON THE ALL-DESIRED NVPTIALS of FREDERIKE the fift, Prince Palatine of Rhene, chiefe Elector, Duke of Bauier, and Arch-Sewer to the Romane EMPIRE. AND ELIZABETH, The onely daughter of IAMES, by the grace of God, King of great Brittaine, France and Ireland, Defender of the FAITH, &c.

q.hi: Illi poena datur, qui ≈øemper amat, nec amatur.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for Samuel Rand, and are to bee ≈øold by Edward Marchant, at his ≈øhop in Pauls Church-yard, ouer again≈øt the Cro≈ø≈øe. 1613.

div.head:
TO THE HONO
‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ GENTLEMAN, SIR Thomas Gerrard of Brinne, Knight Barronet, and one of his Maie≈øties Iu≈øtices for the Countie of Lanca≈øter, AVGVSTINE TAYLOR wi≈øheth all pro≈øperity in Happine≈øse.
div.p:
WHEN all the excellent admired wits of this ≈øo capable Age, in the ≈øpring of thicke furnitur'd inuentions, be≈øtow paines to giue my Patrons a perfect blazon, I willing to thru≈øt my dutifull loue into the Pre≈ø≈øe, longing to ≈øee the ≈øhape of affection in Print; Credo vt e≈øt dementia, Seeing ≈øo many ≈øwelling Mu≈øes, and of ≈øuch apprehen≈øion, that read theirs and mine next together, and you will ≈øay, my ill worke makes their good labours to appeare better then (indeed) they are. Vt ≈øementem feceris, ita & metes: Apply not that Rule to mee, but right worthy Sir, of what I offer willingly, vouch to accept courteou≈øly, as a Monument of my loue, which
time hath borne to the generous family of the Gerrards, and my affection to your worthy ≈øelfe. Knowing you to come from the be≈øt worth of that Aierie, and one of his Maie≈øties re≈øpected, grace my ill-tempered Mu≈øe: and hauing ≈øo worthy a refuge, you ≈øhall hereafter ≈øee it ≈øtart out of Cinders (vnus dies non ≈øat e≈øtad parandam eruditionem) and liue an age that ere-while waxt old with a Sommers day. Vouch to allow of this, till time pre≈øent you with ≈øome greater token of my loue: I commit your de≈øeruing worthine≈ø≈øe to wi≈øhed continuance.

closer.signed: Yours in loue and dutie, AVGVSTINE TAYLOR

lg.l: O Would to God I had the Sun-hatch't wing,
A quill ≈øo worth to tell of banquetting:
Mine is ≈øo partcht in cinders of my wants,
De≈øert craues Vowels, Art giues Con≈øonants.
One ≈øence is ≈øleeping, and that ≈øence is muffled,
This ≈øence is ≈øtudying, that and all are ruffled:
Amazed, wakened, called, incompo≈øed,
Moued, affected, gathered, indi≈øclo≈øed.
The perfect blazon true fame ≈øhall ≈øupport,
Will tell how farre my Art is heere too ≈øhort:
Were I but ≈øeated on the Mu≈øes mountaine,
To quaffe my quart of that ripe dropping fountaine,
Where Tully once wonne that immortall prai≈øe,
From that Parna≈ø≈øus fetcht his Romaine phra≈øe:
Vnder that Helicon my Mu≈øe ≈øhould ≈øing,
Not altogether prai≈øe of Englands King,
But in my notes Fames whi≈øpering breath ≈øhould bleed,
De≈øeruing prai≈øes to his worthy ≈øeed.
You now mu≈øt thinke I felt my wit but poore,
I napt an howre, and ment to write no more.
Now apparitions, now good, and then bad,
I'le tell thee England of a dreame I had.
Suppo≈øe I ≈øate vpon the Cliffes of Douer,
(From flowery Kent) the Ocean to looke ouer.
When in a morning old Aurora's hue
Had clad the heauens in their ancient blew.
Night went ≈øo fa≈øt, and day appear'd ≈øo plaine,
The eies di≈øea≈øed of the Northerne waine:
Artipholax blu≈øter'd in his muffled bed,
Pale Luna to the We≈øterne confines fled;
White teames of mi≈øt ran ≈øtealing downe the riuers,
Eclip≈øed man≈øions now were craz'd in ≈øhiuers,
My greedy ≈ølumber ≈øhew'd my eies, me thought
Strange nouelties that cheerefull day had brought.
The fir≈øt I gaz'd at, ≈øeem'd a rocke of ≈øtone,
Which Sea-gods (≈øometime) v≈ø'd to ≈øit vpon,
Incompa≈øt round with ≈øeas on euery ≈øide,
Fram'd like a ≈øeat, ca≈øt by the ≈øurly tide;
Whereon the faire≈øt Lady was repos'd,
That euer Nature whilome had di≈øclos'd,
Crown'd in all glory, made ≈øo fine and denty,
I ≈øaw one beauty, and in that one plenty.
If euer eye was ≈øummond to a fea≈øt,
My eyes were fea≈øted, and my fea≈øt was be≈øt:
I thought Marpe≈ø≈øa in that princely Chaire
Had there repos'd her ≈øelfe to take the aire,
And ≈øadly ≈øuited in a ≈øolemne cheere,
Did meane to ≈øtay her Lord and Louer there.
And Idas ≈ølow, in needy ≈øpeed di≈øpatching,
He yet was ab≈øent, and ≈øhe yet was watching.
O how I cur≈øt him, (angry at delay)
Hard-hearted man to be ≈øo long away.
The day waxt elder, and the morne ≈øhew'd cleerer,
The heauens pittifull, ≈øent the Sunne to cheere her.
Phoebus appear'd, cloth'd in his fair'≈øt array,
As if prepar'd to ≈øuite a glorious day.
His radiant ≈øplendors ≈øcatter in the skyes,
Her faire perfections ≈øparkle in mine eyes.
I was opinionate the world was done,
I thought the Gods had ≈øent another Sunne.
Then it was ≈øo, by vcnturing, I came
Some paces neerer to this princely Dame.
When I perceiu'd ≈øhe was a mortall creature,
Compo≈øed in the perfect'≈øt mould of Nature,
And in her hand ≈øhe held a little frame,
With this deuice erected in her name.

l.hi: A branch in March, that dy'd to liue in Aprill.

lg.l: Life weeps for death, death crownes a new life ble≈øt;
Thus, friends weep mo≈øt, to know their friends at re≈øt.
In this faire creature ≈øeated thus alone,
A thou≈øand beauties were combin'd in one:
Her golden Tre≈ø≈øes hang'd vncurl'd and ruffl'd,
In a rich Night-gowne ≈øhe was ≈øadly muffl'd.
O had I ≈øeene her ≈øuited in tho≈øe rayes,
Which Courtly cu≈øtome ob≈øerues now-a-dayes,
I eould haue teld yee neerer her great merit,
But ignorance mu≈øt now a part inherit.
Your thoughts mu≈øt cen≈øure, ≈øhe was more theÃÑ faire,
(And being more, I cannot more declare)
And fit to adde a glory to the sky,
A mate (indeed) for maie≈øty to buy,
Crown'd with all graces, and to name in generall,
One beauty matchle≈ø≈øe, and in that one ≈øeuerall.
O had you ≈øeene her, how all beauties mou'd her,
You wold haue prais'd her, if you had not lou'd her.
Thus long I view'd her, raui≈øht more & more,
I turn'd my eyes to glance vpon the ≈øhore,
Where I e≈øpy'd a ≈øtranger ≈øadly ≈øtanding,
Waiting for ≈øhipping, as men do for landing.
Vpon Delphebaes ≈øeat his eyes were gazing,
I ≈øaw a ≈øcutchion by the ≈øunnes bright blazing;
Telling his name, and ouer that was planted
A faire deui≈øe which no perfection wanted.

l.hi: A male Confe≈ø≈øor to a female Prie≈øt.

lg.l: Great men are often actors of oppre≈ø≈øion,
And ≈øhe's the cau≈øe that I mu≈øt make confe≈ø≈øion.
His eies gaz'd at Delpheba as before,
(So ≈øhip-wrackt ≈øea-men v≈øe to do at ≈øhore)
Afflicted, troubled, feared, and tormented,
Di≈øtemper'd, blubber'd, ≈øad, and di≈øcontented,
Complaining, ≈øorrowing, wi≈øhing, nothing gaining,
Sighing, bewailing, crauing, not obtaining,
Seeking for pa≈ø≈øage to Delphebas re≈øting,
Vowing, affecting, calling, and prote≈øting,
Vnto the Powers Diuine he plants prefers,
He had but one life and that was hers.
To raile on Nature then he doth beginne,
That ≈øhe (vnkind) ordain'd him not to ≈øwimme:
To breake his pa≈ø≈øions Phoebus look't more cheerely,
And ≈ømil'd as if hee lou'd a louer deerely,
And halfe re≈øolu'd to let Torbinius pa≈ø≈øe,
From him to her, he ≈øhowes a bridge of gla≈ø≈øe:
Compo≈ød in all parts plea≈øant to behold,
Fram'd by Diuine Art, wonders manifold,
Appear'd to gaze on, yet it ≈øeem'd ≈øo brittle,
The pa≈ø≈øage dangerous and the ≈øafety little;
But loue ≈øo forward in his owne attempts,
And mixes ≈øowre harmes with fraile ≈øweet contents,
Determines now, as men for women would do,
To win his loue, or try what venturing could do;
Enters the bridge with this ra≈øh re≈øolution,
To die for loue, confirmes the old conclu≈øion,
And his boil'd humour in this ≈øort doth cheri≈øh,
To pa≈ø≈øe the bridge, or in the mid≈øt to peri≈øh:
And being di≈øtant from the ≈øandie ≈øide,
Some mea≈øur'd paces, Neptune ≈øends the tide,
And ≈øummons fenny ≈øubiects to new broyles,
Collecting ≈øurges to maintaine new ≈øpoyles.
The houering windes tumbl'd from Eolus wombe,
And in the Ocean gan to digge their Tombe.
The Titan E≈øterne gates, perculliz'd, pale,
Er'≈øt calmes, now ≈øtormes, for gu≈øts a bitter gale.
Nereus warn'd the Sea-gods to the≈øe warres,
And rul'd as Generall in the≈øe vp≈øtart iarres.
Torbinius being on the bridge of gla≈ø≈øe,
Look't downe and ≈øaw th'impatient billowes pa≈ø≈øe,
And with his dul eares, hard the deafe winds muÃÑble,
And with his dim eyes ≈øaw the ≈øurges tumble.
One waue did caper, and that billow wonder'd,
This ≈øurge was angry, and that tempe≈øt thunder'd,
A≈øpiring, threatning death, or future ill,
Shaping, pre≈øenting accidents to kill.
A hurrying mi≈øt comes ≈øudden ≈øtealing in,
Nor he, nor ≈øhe, ≈øaw neither her nor him:
In this ≈øtrange temper pa≈ø≈øionately di≈øtracted,
Torbinius now a ≈øowre part ≈øadly acted;
And all his griefes ≈øprung, as it ≈øeem'd to me,
From the ≈øicke confines of perplexitie.
A thicke-lin'd mi≈øt continu'd 'tweene them two,
(Loue wrapt in wrinkles knowes no worke to do.)
Thus Fortune makes, & thus mad Forune marres,
Loue is ≈øtill Souldier at ≈øuch ciuill warres.
Sighing, lamenting, the≈øe bad broyles to be in,
That he ≈øhould dye, and not his Lady ≈øee him,
When onely for her ≈øake hee ventured thus,
(Loue ≈øees no dangers that ≈øeeme timorus.)
Torbinius. Then to him≈øelfe (I thought) hee did reply,
And ≈øaid; How luckle≈ø≈øe and accur≈øt am I,
Couer'd with fortunes foule di≈ø≈øembling fame,
To dye for her that knowes not who I am?
Oh might I dye my Ladies face before,
I would ≈øay Fortune were a noble Whore,
In her faire ≈øight to end Torbinius date,
O then my death were not vnfortunate,
Then ≈øhe might iu≈øtly ≈øay; here ended he,
That liu'd, and lou'd, and dy'd to honor me:
But Gods, & Seas, & Winds, contemne my plaints,
And their har≈øh Language trippes on Con≈øonants:
Then thus re≈øolu'd, ≈øucceed what ill can proue,
And if I dye, I dye for her I loue.
I left him thus, and turn'd my greedy eyes
Vpon the rocke where faire Delpheba lyes,
Who now in blacke appear'd to me all couer'd,
About the which ≈øad Melancholy houer'd.
Then to Delpheba there (me thought) re≈øorted,
Nymphes and Sea-gods, by their loue tran≈øported,
To comfort her that ≈øeem'd ≈øo much lamenting,
And know the ≈øad cau≈øe of her di≈øcontenting.
Delpheba. To whom ≈øhe an≈øwer'd, I haue lo≈øt a friend,
Which winged Fame can nere too much commend.
O would to God I could Olimpus rai≈øe,
And there ≈øet Trophies to his endle≈ø≈øe prai≈øe:
And for his death, I cho≈øe this place to mone,
"The teares are true≈øt that are ≈øhed alone."
A dying life weepes for a liuing death,
A tale vn≈øeemely for a true friends breath.
And as it is, it may be ≈øomething better,
Fortune's a ≈øtrumpet, and ≈øhe is my debter,
Promi≈øing be≈øt, when ≈øhe perform'd the wor≈øt:
Things that ≈øound har≈øhli'≈øt, I haue had tho≈øe fir≈øt.
The Gods and Nymphs began to tune their throtes,
To keepe a con≈øort with her cheerele≈ø≈øe notes.
In this Diapa≈øon deepe, ≈øad harmonie,
Dull ≈øences ≈øtriue for ≈øorrowes victory,
Chimes iterating on this blacke-mouth'd dinne;
I then perceiu'd Torbinius comming in,
Seeing Delpheba in ≈øuch pa≈ø≈øions ≈øuited,
In mourning weeds ≈øuch ill cheere pro≈øecuted,
Attires him≈øelfe in ≈øorrowes for her ≈øake,
Torbinius. The Counter-tennor of her part to take.
Vnto the fair'≈øt my ≈øeruice I commend,
Tis onely thou my loue did apprehend,
All dangers pa≈øt compared to this prize,
Seemes like a darke way to a Paradize.
And on all dangers what's he would not venter,
Tho≈øe all being pa≈øt, might to thy pre≈øence enter?
And am I happy to be comne thus neere thee?
And art thou kind? or can my comming cheere thee?
I'le weare what thou wears, what thou loues Ile keep
I'le laugh wheÃÑ thou ≈ømiles, wheÃÑ thou ≈øighes Ile weep.
What mo≈øt ≈øhall grieue thee, it ≈øhal mo≈øt tormeÃÑt me,
What be≈øt ≈øhal plea≈øe thee, that ≈øhal be≈øt conteÃÑt me.
If Natures pride be but ≈øo kinde as faire,
All ≈øtormes are pa≈øt, I do not care for Care.
I loue thee now when ≈øad laments increa≈øe,
To haue thy loue when pa≈ø≈øions turne to peace.
Expecting Sommer when cold March is pa≈øt,
I'le wait ten months to haue a May at la≈øt.
Il'e reape no Harue≈øt but where thou ha≈øt ≈øowne,
My loue in thy loue ≈øhall exceed thy owne.
And but in thee, no hope, no hap, no health,
And but in thee no will, no wi≈øh, no wealth.
For what thou mournes, I waile, thy part I take;
Now ble≈ø≈øed be all women for thy ≈øake.
In thee I loue, in thee I onely liue,
'Tis I that begges, and it is thou can giue.
Nor do I craue thee more then may be≈øeeme thee,
Thou art my be≈øt hap, and I mo≈øt e≈øteeme thee.
Make me a ≈øeruant at thy ≈øacred ≈øhrine;
This life is that life, let that life be mine.
What good, what ill, what life, what all to thee,
That good, that ill, that life, that all to me.
Comforts attend thee, all good hap befriend thee,
Duties commend thee, wi≈øhed power defend thee.
Make me thy ≈øeruant, ≈ømile on my reque≈øt,
Delphebaes Scholler I am now profe≈øt.
At Lunaes full the skyes ≈øeeme in their ≈øtate,
At Princes birthes the earth lookes fortunate.
The one decayes when in her chiefe≈øt prime,
The other dyes when in his hopeful'≈øt time.
My teares are falling for a friend that lou'd me,
He's dead, he's gone, & thus his death hath mou'd me
His death is liuing, and my life is dying,
My life is creeping, and his death is flying.
My lo≈ø≈øe, his gaine: his wealth my wo compriz'd,
Are two contraries ≈øtrangely exerciz'd.
My plaints and teares, and ≈øorrowes, ≈øtill augmented,
Complaining, blubber'd, la≈øting more tormented.
Much pitty'd cheerene≈ø≈øe, much lamented neerne≈ø≈øe,
Vnharbor'd, fearele≈ø≈øe, vnfrequented neerene≈ø≈øe,
De≈øolate, di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, fru≈øtrate, vn-re≈øpected,
Incommitate, oppre≈ø≈øed, complicate, neglected:
And of all the≈øe ills there is but one mother,
Pale Death, leaues our life this gift, and no other.
The earth and Mortals mu≈øt ≈øubmit their Powers,
To ≈øerue a VVill aboue this will of ours.
Of what earth can do I may iu≈øtly vaunt,
VVhat heauens will haue I mu≈øt needly grant.
O death, √¥ death, thy ≈øpoiles I cannot mend,
Yet I'le performe the duty of a friend:
Some friends liue yet, 'tis you appeares to me
VVill be a≈ø≈øociate in my mi≈øery.
You, you, Torbinius, for your great de≈øert,
Shall haue the be≈øt place in my conquer'd heart:
My loue, ≈øhall your loue pay with wi≈øht reward,
And with Delpheba be in be≈øt regard:
Expecting ≈øorrowes will be ≈øooner pa≈øt,
And ioy (though long) yet will be here at la≈øt:
The skies look cheerly, that e're-while lok't ≈øtrangly,
The ≈øeas are ≈ømiling that but now were angry,
I thinke the Gods (together) haue decreed
To change our muffled melancholy weed,
And for our late lamented Funerals,
Now to erect contented Nuptials;
In pledge of loue I greete thee with a ki≈ø≈øe,
I owe thee more, ≈øuppo≈øe, by giuing this.
Now let me craue you to decide this thought
And be not partiall; which of the≈øe two ought
To be lamented more? her teares are ≈øowne,
For her friends harue≈øt that pale death hath mowne:
His teares are ≈øpent for her calamities,
That ≈øeemes a mother of ≈øad mi≈øeries.
Shee weepes for him that neuer can do better,
Hee weepes for her that yet is natures debter:
Then rightly ≈øcan'd if iudgement rightly do,
'Twill ≈øay her teares, no wi≈øe worke takes them too:
Whether ≈øhe weepe for freind ≈øake, or her owne,
'Tis yet a que≈øtion, and it is not knowne,
If for her owne ≈øake (I mu≈øt needs be plaine)
Shee thought by his life to reape future gaine;
This wailing no man rightly can commend,
For thus ≈øhe proues a very vnkind freind.
If ≈øhe lament for his ≈øake, wi≈øe men ≈øaith,
Shee ≈øhowes th'imbecillity of her faith.
And by that weakene≈ø≈øe it appeares to me
Shee thinkes her ≈øelfe in better ca≈øe then he:
She ought not t'weepe that he hath run ≈øo fa≈øt,
But at her ≈ølow pace that mu≈øt go at la≈øt.
But now (me-thinkes) Delphebas wondrous wi≈øe,
To make a Summer of her Winters eies:
All friendly duties are di≈øcharged duly,
Old Natures loue is paid by wi≈øedome truly.
The Sun, and Aire, & houering Winds do mutter,
Conceiuing more ioy, then dumbe ≈øence can vtter:
The Sea-gods whi≈øper iump in all opinions,
To order peace through their vntil'd Dominions,
And tooke their leaue, all Tempe≈øts now are gone,
Torbinius and Delpheba now alone,
They ioyned hands and then (me thought) did pa≈ø≈øe
Backe to the ≈øhore where great attending was,
And being landed dangers all bereft them,
My dreame was ended and in ioy I left them.

lg.head: Ex a≈øpectis na≈øcitur amor.
lg.l: When Lordly Phaebus left his E≈øterne Ile,
And with his ≈øplendor that Titanian ≈ømile,
Came like a Prince from th'orientall gate,
So richly ≈øuted in his robes of State.
The chearele≈ø≈øe earth ≈øhooke off her dewy tre≈ø≈øes,
And from darke curtaines now her ≈øhades digre≈ø≈øes.
I lookt about me, Douer was not neere mee,
That now contents me, which but then did feare me.
I then perceiu'd 'twas on the bancke of Thames,
That I retain'd th'inuention of my dreames:
And as the plea≈øant Riuer fa≈øt did glide,
With pratling murmur by the Kenti≈øh ≈øide,
I laid me downe neere to a Willow roote,
Who≈øe branches farre had ouer-growne the foote;
The ≈øearching Sunne not in a day obtain'd,
To ≈øee the ≈øtocke whereby ≈øhe was maintain'd.
'Twas publicke knowne a fairer tree then this,
Ne're neighbour'd neere the bankes of Thame≈øis.
I there repos'd vpon this dewy brimme.
And, as I thought, the Tide came ≈øtealing in.
Thames that e're while gaz'd vpon Phoebus prime,
Turn'd now againe to watch for his decline:
Night went, day came, all ioyes on tiptoes ≈øhiuer,
A ≈ønow white Swanne came playing vp the Riuer:
Ruffling his plumes and in ≈øuch ioy did ≈øwimme,
You would haue ≈øworne the Tide much fauor'd him.
His ≈øo faire brea≈øt dinted the furrowing I≈øis,
VVho ≈øaith he ≈øaw a worthier bird then this is?
Both Kent and E≈ø≈øex gather'd neere to ≈øee,
VVhere the fir≈øt landing of this Swanne might bee:
Faire Middle-≈øex pul'd downe her maske and Fan,
To ≈øee the Tide bring in this ≈øtranger Swan.
O how it ioy'd me to heare mu≈øicke greet him
In ≈øeuerall tunes, and other Swannes did meete him;
Their Princely ≈øalutations ≈øure were ≈øuch,
As London neuer ≈øaw of mirth ≈øo much.
Now, in the end, where this faire Swan took landing,
Let none decide but tho≈øe of vnder≈øtanding.

lg.head: Qui≈øque pote≈øt rebus ≈øuccurrere, nemo diebus.
lg.l: To Fredericke. Omnia fert tempus. VVhen thou (great Prince) from Rhenus natiue clime
(Richer then Tagus, faire as Florentine,)
Pul'd vp thy En≈øignes, clad thy ratling Sailes,
The wind, thy vyage, and the Tide preuailes,
To bring thee to our Ea≈øterne tumbling Thames,
The Ocean's me≈ø≈øage to great Britaines IAMES:
And may that howre in happy times to come
Be cal'd thy landing in Elizium:
Happy thy birth, more fortunate thy life,
Pro≈øperous thy voyage, vertuous thy wife:
Vertue, Virginity, Honour, Natures pride,
Thou art her Husband, and Shee is thy Bride,
And con≈øecrated ≈øhall that day be thought:
The howre and I≈øis that thee hither brought,
Shall be erected in great Fames Regi≈øter,
And thy reward is prou'd a Princes Si≈øter.
Fame cannot chu≈øe but impe her pinion'd wing,
And in loud Mu≈øicke for thy welcome ≈øing:
Fea≈øt thee, attend thee, and in more e≈øteeme
Then Cleopatra the Egiptian Queene
Fea≈øted Marke Anthony, nor can thou ≈øay,
Thou came in Autumne, it was rather May;
Onely cro≈ø≈øes of lamented Funerals,
Chanc't in the Frontiers of thy Nuptials.
∆≤xor bona, optima po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øio. O worthy FREDERIKE, it was Lordly done,
That thou thy ≈øelfe in per≈øon hither come.
It ≈øhewes thy minde is Noble, and indeed,
Sprung from the airie where true Eagles breed.
Eagles in Cages, are but Kings in Towers,
And but enioy the name of Princely powers.
Kings are earths Gods, and Gods liu'd not at home,
But had a mind in forraine Climes to rome.
'Tis regi≈øter'd not many Ages ≈øince,
Solon of Athens was to choo≈øe a Prince:
Being demanded how he meant to know,
A man well worthy of a Crowne (or no)
An≈øwer'd: If this choyce be to me a≈ø≈øig'nd,
Il'e choo≈øe a Prince, and onely by the minde:
If inward Noble, I heard wi≈øe men tell,
Hee's worth a Crowne, and 'twill ≈øeeme pa≈ø≈øing wel.
By this I noted, how thou truly merits
The perfect beautie that thou now inherits,
And ≈øure ≈øhe thinkes thee a right worthy Prince,
That would thy trauels (for her ≈øake) conuince.
If all that trauel'd might enioy like ≈øtore,
The lame would run, that ≈øcarce could go before.
Who would not trauell, and to them owe duties,
VVhen each eye finds perfections in their beauties?
Liue long, great Prince, and be thy cho≈øen prize
A faire terre≈øtriall happy Paradize.
To Germany. In time hereafter, yet remember Thame,
How once ≈øhe welcom'd a yong Prince of Rhene.
lg.trailer: Amicos nouos parans, ne obliui≈øcaris veterum.

lg.head: Virtus in ≈øe habet omnia bona.
lg.l: To Elizab. Faire Prince≈ø≈øe, vertuous; what to good belongs
Thou art the mother to, Applau≈øe ≈øo throngs,
T'attend on thee, and 'mong≈øt the re≈øt my part,
It is thy merites makes my loue and Art,
Vprear'd on tiptoes, and yet would a≈øpire
To giue thee what is due, and my de≈øire,
Tels but thy name, and it is all I can,
Tho≈øe do no more, that profe≈ø≈øe what I am:
Nor can, nor neede, for all remembreth
That thou art onely that Elizabeth,
Which forraine Ecchoes in loud notes doth ring,
To be the daughter of great Britaines King.
Nor is it I that labours in thy prai≈øe,
I know thy name's thy Trumpet, and can rai≈øe
It ≈øelfe to'th' height of honour; why I write
To tell my duty, and this Epithite,
Is ≈øtuft full of Affection: what if poore?
The gifts are great when giuers haue no more:
And ≈øhould indeed be thought our Alexander,
Macedo's ≈øonne: the Ea≈øterne great Commander,
Was nam'd in Cottages by th'low'≈øt degree;
Then of a Miller: √¥ good God ≈øaid hee,
There's not a Miller now but knowes my name,
Meaning indeed Report addes life to Fame;
Fame's like the Sunne, and not di≈ødaines to view
Both Courts and Cottages, neither doth rue
Of their great courte≈øies: marke well each ≈øeate,
And great men proud, makes them vn≈øeemely great.
A woman ≈øilent, great by birth before,
So richly dre≈øt, Fame ≈øhapeth more and more.
Eliza, England truly boa≈øts of thee
To be the Trea≈øurer of each Trea≈øurie,
That euer grac't a woman: mu≈øt we leaue thee?
Il'e now tru≈øt Fortune; for't did not deceiue me.
I euer thought ≈øo faire a flower as this,
Should grace ≈øome other place then Thame≈øis.
And yet faire Prince≈ø≈øe, vertuous I meane,
Remember Thames when thou art ≈øet on Rhene.
How gladly thunder'd ≈øhe lowd Epithets,
Profe≈ø≈øed peales, all to her Nuptiall Rites?
Did ≈øhe not ≈øummon gazers to thy Reuels,
And what was knotty, with her tide ≈øhe leuels?
Di≈ø-gorged Canons fire in ≈øeuerall ≈øhapes,
Enemies ≈øuffer when true Chri≈øtians ≈øcapes.
Meteors i'th aire, ≈øhe did her owne ≈øelfe choake,
All London thought Thames wold di≈ø≈øolue to ≈ømoke,
And all the Reuels this faire Floud did make,
VVorthy Eliza, was but for thy ≈øake.
VVhen thou wa≈øt married, ≈øhe by chance heard tell,
And did but this becau≈øe ≈øhe loues thee well.
At thy depart, ≈øhee'l follow thee and weepe,
And then ≈øhee'l turne thy worthy ≈øtocke to ≈øeeke,
And finding them, ≈øhee'l leaue her ≈øobbing moane,
Onely ≈øhee'l each day ≈øee where thou ha≈øt gone.
VVell may ≈øhe boa≈øt ≈øhe was of able power,
To grace faire Rhenus with an Engli≈øh flower.
And when the≈øe two meet in great Oceans,
Thei'l know each other by their natiue Swans.
So by this marriage, Eccho vnder≈øtands,
'Twill make acquainted both the Seas and Lands.
A happy time, a good world may it be,
After yong Frederike came to match with thee.
O noted howre, ble≈øt be the God aboue,
Thou but leaues England to enioy thy loue;
And for thy ab≈øence Britaine in a mends
Hath gained great ≈øtore of true Chri≈øtian friends.
Liue, liue, faire Prince≈ø≈øe, may thy ≈øeede, thy fame,
In cinders, a≈øhes keepe aliue thy name.
lg.trailer: Foelicitas e≈øt voluptas, quam paenitudo nulla ≈øequitur.

lg.head: Creator per creaturas cogno≈øcendus.
lg.l: Heu, ≈øome will ≈øay when they haue lo≈øt a friend
And make his funerall, e're they ≈øee his end;
A number now are buried in conceit
When they'r (indeed) not ≈øicke, yet teares will wait.
There is a death in ab≈øence ≈øome ≈øuppo≈øe,
Who thinkes there is? for I am none of tho≈øe:
Is England loth to loo≈øe ≈øo faire a creature
As art thy ≈øelfe Eliza? √¥, Dame Nature
Ca≈øt thee not in her mould of be≈øt perfection,
Euer to liue a Virgin, heauens direction
Smil'd at thy birth and meant to make a mother,
That when thou dies thou may leaue ≈øuch another.
Virginity dies a Traitor, her po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions
Like traitors Earldomes make ≈øuch large digre≈ø≈øions
They leaue no Heires at all, by this I ≈øee
A Virgine cannot leaue po≈øterity.
To Elizab. As thou art honour'd for a Virgins life,
Thou ≈øtill ≈øhalt liue, becau≈øe a happy wife.
I heard it ≈øaid, the fir≈øt time Ne≈øtor ≈ømil'd,
Was when he ≈øaw a woman great with child;
And being asked why he ≈ømil'd (and ble≈øt her,)
Said he, the next age will remember Ne≈øtor.
And thou faire Prince≈ø≈øe in the age to come,
Shall liue by Fame when Natures life hath done:
And death hath truely paid her Fame to time
Shall build their blazons to the ≈øeed of thine.
lg.trailer:
Fama velox e≈øt, cre≈øcit
que eundo.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.l: LOue, like, leaue, looke at other ripe inuentions:
And ≈øee how farre mine differs from the re≈øt:
The≈øe are indifferent, tho≈øe are of the be≈øt.
Their's good, mine wor≈øer, good may wor≈øer ≈ømother,
The be≈øt appeares be≈øt, when 'tis by the wor≈øt:
How can that be? yes; ≈øet by either other,
And that which lookes be≈øt men will choo≈øe that fir≈øt.
Mine's poorely ≈øuted, yet my Patrons name's
So ≈øeated in the fore-head of my Ver≈øe,
'Twill moue the Reader to be≈øtow ≈øome paines,
And iterate that which I do rehear≈øe:
And when thou finds my Poems barely dre≈øt,
Smile to thy ≈øelfe (and ≈øay) he did his be≈øt.

div.head: Laus in prima ≈øonat, virtus in fine coronat.

l.hi: FAme's yet an Infant, Eccho's of report,
Now impes her pinions, and in ≈øcattering ≈øort
Applauds what good's in acting, generall prai≈øe
Crownes the beginning, and the end to rai≈øe,
Vertue's about to giue a Lawrell wreath
VVhen Time the merits of your time hath gather'd,
You ≈øhall appeare yong, when your time is wither'd.

div.trailer: Praemia victorum pendent a fine laborum.
